key_insight: Combining spiking neural computation with a lightweight video transformer yields a power-efficient, event-driven segmentation model that targets real-time surgical scene understanding on resource-constrained hardware.
problem_solved: Addresses the high compute, latency, and power demands of state-of-the-art segmentation models that prevent real-time deployment in surgical environments and edge devices.
method: Introduce a spike-driven video transformer that encodes video frames into sparse, event-like spike representations to exploit temporal sparsity.
Use event-driven attention/processing and a compact segmentation head to reduce computation and energy compared to dense frame-by-frame models.
Design training strategies (e.g., surrogate gradients / temporal consistency losses) to maintain segmentation accuracy while enabling low-power inference.
impact: Makes high-quality surgical scene segmentation feasible on embedded OR devices, enabling lower-latency intra-operative assistance and opening paths for energy-aware video models in other real-time medical applications.

paper_title: Surgical Scene Segmentation using a Spike-Driven Video Transformer with Real-Time Potential
paper_authors: Shihao Zou, Jingjing Li, Wei Ji, Jincai Huang, Kai Wang
